Virtuals in Mongoose

... About 2 min

# Virtuals in Mongoose

VirtualsÂ are additional fields for a given model. Their values can be set manually or automatically with defined functionality. A common virtual property is the full name of a person, composed of user's first and last name.

Keep in mind:Â virtual properties don't get persisted in the database. They only exist logically and are not written to the document's collection.

# Mongoose Schema

We'll use the user schema below for further examples. The user schema has two properties indicating the user's first and last name:Â firstÂ andÂ last.

// define user schema
var userSchema = new Schema({
    first: String,
    last: String
});

// compile our model
var User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);

// create a document
var user = new User({
    first: 'Peter',
    last: 'Parker'
});

Assume we want to get the full name ofÂ user, we can do this manually appending theÂ firstÂ toÂ lastÂ property:

console.log(user.first + ' ' + user.last); // Peter Parker

# Define a Virtual Property

Actually, there is a better way of getting the full name of a user:Â virtual fields. With virtuals, you benefit of writing the name concatenation mess only once.

Mongoose splits the definiton of virtual fields intoÂ GETÂ andÂ SETÂ methods.

# Get Method

The virtualsÂ getÂ method is a function returning a the virtual value. You can do complex processing or just concatenate single document field values.

userSchema.virtual('fullname').get(function() {
    return this.first + ' ' + this.last;
});

The code example above just concatenates theÂ firstÂ andÂ lastÂ property values. With that, the virtualÂ fullnameÂ property now will print the same output as above:

console.log(user.fullname); // Peter Parker

# Set Method

setter methods are useful to split strings or do other operations. Define a virtualÂ setter by passing a proper function and execute your desired processing. The example below splits the passedÂ nameÂ variable at any whitespace.

userSchema.virtual('fullname').set(function (name) {
  var split = name.split(' ');
  this.first = split[0];
  this.last = split[1];
});

The first part ofÂ nameÂ is assigned to theÂ firstÂ and the second part to theÂ lastÂ property. ThisÂ setÂ method will override the previous model values and assign the ones we pass asÂ fullnameÂ property.

var ironman = new User({
    first: '',
    last: ''
});

ironman.fullname = 'Tony Stark';
console.log(ironman.first); // Tony
console.log(ironman.last);  // Stark

# Queries and Field Selection

Virtuals areÂ NOTÂ available for document queries or field selection. Only non-virtual properties work for queries and field selections.

# Conclusion

As you see,Â virtualÂ properties aren't static model properties. They are additional model functions returning values based on the default schema fields.
